name: Sun (Sol)
notes: eight recognized planets and more dwarf planets

name: Alpha Centauri
notes: flare star, two confirmed planets (b, 2016, and d, 2022) and a third disputed planet (c, 2019)

name: Barnard's Star (BD+04°3561a)
notes: flare star, largest-known proper motion, one refuted planet (b)

name: Wolf 359 (CN Leonis)
notes: flare star, has 1 candidate & 1 refuted planet

name: Alpha Canis Majoris
notes: brightest star in the night sky

name: Ran (Epsilon Eridani)
notes: three circumstellar disks, one confirmed planet (AEgir, 2000) and one candidate (c, 2002)

name: Lacaille 9352 (Gliese 887)
notes: two planets, b and c, with equivocal evidence for a third in the habitable zone (2020)

name: 61 Cygni
notes: First star (besides Sun) to have measured distance. Possible circumstellar disk.

name: 61 Cygni
notes: Flare star, with possible planet or brown dwarf. Possible circumstellar disk.

name: Groombridge 34 (Gliese 15)
notes: flare star, two known planets (Ab, 2014, and Ac, 2018)

name: Tau Ceti (BD−16°295)
notes: one debris disk, four confirmed planets (e, f, g, and h) (2012, 2017), four candidate planets (b, c, d, and "i") (2012, 2019)

name: YZ Ceti (LHS 138)
notes: flare star, three planets (b, c, and d) (2017)

name: Luyten's Star (BD+05°1668)
notes: two planets (b, c) (2017) and two suspected planets (d, e) (2019)

name: Lacaille 8760 (AX Microscopii)
notes: brightest M dwarf star in night sky, flare star

name: Van Maanen's star (Gliese 35, LHS 7)
notes: closest-known free-floating white dwarf, third-known white dwarf, possible debris disk (1917)

name: TZ Arietis (Gliese 83.1, L 1159-16)
notes: flare star, has one confirmed planet (b)

name: Gliese 687 (LHS 450, BD+68°946)
notes: possible flare star, two planets (b) (2014) and (c) (2020)

name: Groombridge 1618 (Gliese 380)
notes: flare star, one suspected debris disk

name: Gliese 832
notes: possible flare star, two planets; one confirmed (b (2008)), and the other now refuted (c (2014))

name: Gliese 752 (Wolf 1055, HD 180617)
notes: very small and very dim red dwarf

name: HR 7703 (279 G. Sagittarii, HD 191408, Gliese 783, IRAS 20079-3614)
HR 7703 (279 G. Sagittarii, HD 191408, Gliese 783, IRAS 20079-3614)
82 G. Eridani (e Eridani, Gliese 139, HD 20794)
notes: has 3 confirmed planets, 3 candidate planets, hot and cold dust disks
